title: 110_hr4818
content: The Act may be cited as the "Detectives Nemorin and Andrews Anti-Gun Trafficking Act of 2008" and addresses illegal gun trafficking. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include penalties for offering to sell, transfer, or barter multiple firearms, including handguns, assault weapons, shotguns, rifles, or machineguns, with at least one being stolen or with altered serial numbers. The amended Section 924 of title 18, United States Code includes penalties for offering firearms for sale, transfer, or barter to individuals prohibited from possessing a firearm under certain conditions. The amended Section 924 of title 18, United States Code imposes fines and imprisonment for violating federal or state laws related to firearms. SEC. 3. Expansion of Project Safe Neighborhoods amends Section 104 of the 21st Century Department of Justice Appropriations Authorization Act to include illegal gun trafficking in subsection (a) and changes the year in subsection (b) from 2002 to 2008. SEC. 4. Report to the Congress. SEC. 4. REPORT TO THE CONGRESS. The Attorney General must submit a biennial report to Congress detailing traced firearms used in crimes, Federal firearms licensees with multiple traced firearms, and prosecutions under specific sections of the United States Code. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PENALTY FOR POSSESSION OF A STOLEN FIREARM DURING THE COMMISSION OF A FELONY. Section 924 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a penalty for receiving, possessing, or selling stolen firearms or ammunition during a crime punishable by imprisonment exceeding 1 year. Offenders can face up to 5 years in prison. Additionally, a National Crime Information Center Stolen Gun File is established. The Federal Bureau of Investigation provides the National Crime Information Center Gun File to the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives for crime gun traces. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives searches the Stolen Gun File for each firearm submitted for tracing. If a firearm is found to be stolen, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives notifies the requesting law enforcement agency. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives notifies law enforcement agencies about firearm ownership information and returns stolen firearms to the rightful owner if no longer needed for investigations. The Attorney General is required to establish the National Instant Stolen Gun Check System within 2 years. The Attorney General is mandated to establish a national instant stolen gun check system that allows licensees to quickly determine if a firearm is stolen. The system will search the National Crime Information Center Stolen Gun File and inform the licensee of the firearm's status. The Attorney General is required to establish a national instant stolen gun check system to inform licensees if a firearm is stolen. The system will notify licensees and law enforcement of its existence and maintain permanent records of all system contacts. Federal Firearms Licensees must contact the National Instant Stolen Gun Check System before receiving a firearm from a non-licensee. This requirement is outlined in section 922(s) of title 18, United States Code. The Nemorin and Andrews Anti-Gun Trafficking Act of 2008 requires licensed firearms dealers to verify the identity of a person and contact the national instant stolen gun check system before receiving a firearm from a non-licensee. The Nemorin and Andrews Anti-Gun Trafficking Act of 2008 mandates licensed firearms dealers to verify the identity of a person and contact the national instant stolen gun check system before receiving a firearm from a non-licensee. The system assigns a unique identification number to the transaction and provides it to the licensee if the firearm is not indicated as stolen. If the system indicates that a firearm is stolen, the licensee must contact law enforcement for instructions on handling the firearm and gathering information on the seller. Failure to comply may result in action by the Attorney General. The Attorney General can suspend or revoke a license and impose a fine if a firearm is stolen. This does not limit other authorities under section 923. Recordkeeping requirements for receiving firearms under section 922(s) are also specified. The regulations require the importer, manufacturer, or dealer to retain records of information, identification documents, and unique identification numbers for firearm transactions. SEC. 7. ADDITIONAL PENALTY FOR POSSESSION OF A FIREARM WITH AN OBLITERATED SERIAL NUMBER DURING THE COMMISSION OF A FELONY. This section amends Section 924 of title 18, United States Code, by adding a penalty for possessing a firearm with a removed, obliterated, or altered serial number during the commission of a felony. The penalty includes a term of imprisonment of up to 5 years in addition to the punishment for the underlying crime. SEC. 8 enhances penalties for using a stolen firearm or a firearm with an obliterated serial number during a crime of violence or drug trafficking. The amendment to Section 924(c)(1)(A) of title 18, United States Code, increases the minimum sentences for such offenses to 7, 9, and 12 years respectively.
